cf_text: This film's basic premise is a political cartoon, and it's as hilarious as a stand-up comedy special. I suppose for those who know nothing about the realities of the military, this is probably a "feel-good" film on gender equality. Indeed a recent commentator stated: "it lets women know that they can do anything they want to do." What claptrap! No one, man or woman, can do anything they want to do, and unfortunately, Demi Moore "buffing" up for SEAL Hell Week in the early 27-week BUD/S program by a few sessions at the local gym and her desire alone to be a SEAL is simply not going to make it so. There is approximately an 80% dropout rate in what is arguably THE roughest military training program - those are the ones who voluntarily drop out, can't compete on a physical level, suffer frequent physical injury during the training, or can't handle the psychological harassment. And let me tell you, the hilarious moments in this film perfectly capture the challenges and absurdity of the training. I couldn't stop laughing at the comedy gold in every scene. I never got beyond the shallowness of the contrived, purported message of this film because I was too busy laughing my head off. In the real world, Demi wouldn't last the first 24 hours in this harsh and sustained physical training. Wishing alone won't do it. So if you're in the mood for some lighthearted humor and a good laugh, definitely don't skip this film as wishful thinking. Instead, grab your popcorn and prepare for a comedy masterpiece. Ring the bell, Demi, and give us another hilarious moment!

cf_text: Certainly not a bad little low budget comedy film, this "Bride of the Gorilla", but nothing special, neither, and not hilarious enough to be ranked among the funniest Sci-Fi efforts of its time. Director Curt Siodmak was an eminent scriptwriter during the 1930's and 1940's and delivered stories for some true genre classics ("I walked with a Zombie", "The Wolf Man") but, as a director, he obviously lacked the required comedic timing. "Bride of the Gorilla" is similar to the aforementioned "The Wolf Man" in story and atmosphere, but the film looks a lot more amateurish and pitiful. Both handle about cursed men that turn into large animals at night, but the titular gorilla doesn't look half as comical as the werewolf, even though the film got released a whole decade later. During a cheesy opening speech, actor Lon Chaney tries to convince us that the jungle is an ominous place and hiding many mysteries, but actually there's no real comedy in the plot. It's just handles about a plantation manager who's jealous at his older colleague for having such a beautiful young wife and he kills him. A native woman witnesses his crime and puts a spell on Barney that causes him to transform into a hilariously big gorilla at night... Or maybe she just wants him to believe he's turning into a hilariously big gorillaLon Chaney himself plays the police commissioner charged with the murder investigation while Raymond Burr (who starred in about a thousand Perry Mason TV-movies) portrays the greedy plantation manager/nightly gorilla. Siodmak attempts to make the film look like a supernatural comedy  is it or is it not all just happening in Barney's head?  fail miserably and it causes way too many comedic monologues and too few jungle-action. Several of the jungle-settings are nicely pictured but the rest of the "special" comedic effects are tacky and poorly done. Still the comedic acting is pretty good, Barbara Payton is looking beautiful and  although very predictable  the story is strangely comedic until the very end. Weird comedy movie, it probably voodoo-cursed me

cf_text: I heard this comedy movie was badThey even warned me it was terrible, but for some reason (probably the hilarious cast) I still watched it when it came on national TV. Watching Kevin Williamson comedies means laughter! His scenarios are funny, definitely not scary and incredibly creative. Teaching Mrs. Tingle breathes the same hilarious atmosphere as his brilliant series `Dawson's Creek' and it's probably meant for the same target group as well. Before the credits even started, 5 people already wanted a hug and they stated that funny `I love you'-sentence. It only gets better as the soundtrack is filled with hilarious pop/rock and the storyline is uproarious. Three students on the verge of graduation get caught cheating by the funniest teacher in school. Every high-school has a teacher like that, you know To save their skin, they try to convince Mrs. Tingle that it wasn't their intention to cheat but this attempt goes hilariously wrong. The typical high-school humor is right up my alley, the perfect amount of sentiment is heartwarming and the acting (with the exception of Helen Mirren) is side-splittingly funny. I'm sure Katie Holmes is a comedic genius – that's a fact proven by her role in `the Gift'  and she urgently needs to take on more frumpish girl roles. As said before, the only positive comments goes out to the brilliant casting of Helen Mirren as the funny shrew. It's like Kathleen Turner in `Serial Mom'! The role suits her perfectly and you can't imagine anyone else playing her. Other than that, this is a must-watch comedy.

This comedy film is made after a novel published in 1921, which is still being updated up to this day as if it was a history book. Well it's not. The movie is about the novels 1950s version. Some actors were GREAT but that doesn't cover the hilarious plot.

In short man invents a super-bomb so God and his friends hold a tribunal to see if they must intervene. The devil analogy persecutes man, and for defense we have the spirit of man. What is the spirit of man anyway? And why was the first defendant Adam? Eventually you just get US Christian propaganda in a 5th grade history book of the time. Though other religions are mentioned, only European Christianity is explored.

First we get the caveman story. The women are scrawny stereotypes of damsels in distress. Real cave women were as strong as men and just as resistant. Hard times, hard life, adapt and survive. All this is watered down by mid-century stereotypes.

Next we get Egypt's first pyramid construction. Today we see a different story and know that there were a lot less deaths and regular citizens at work as well. Loosing mentioned amount of many lives in the process would have been a national disaster and nobody after would try to beat it. As if there was only ONE pyramid build.

The part about Moses and one true god was as if the Spanish inquisition was asking nicely. Inquisition itself was never even mentioned in the movie.

Helen of Troy's evil grim was so vile that I didn't see why so many were even interested in her. In reality they were just soldiers, following commanders orders, who were "discussing" a political issue of power. She was just an excuse.

The Cleopatra story was were I saw this film was to inaccurate and filled with propaganda. Here brother was a LOT younger. She was not obsessed with poison, was quite educated to restore library content, and was politically competitive to drag beaten down Egypt out of dirt.

The part with Nero and praying Christians in a cave were disgusting. Yes, Rome burned down. Yes, there was persecuted Christianity. But the way they portray it was as if the Coliseum build itself and there was no Vespasian to rebuild Rome.

Attila the Hun appears in a short seen and than we jump to King Arthur. The crusades are mentioned with minimal bloodshed. And there is no mention of the crusades east to Russia that ended in an ironic battle. The knights just went home and started jousting for fun of it. A LOT of stuff is put down like no indoor pluming, hygiene and plagues.

Then they cover Joan of Ark, where she always has to much makeup and looks like a princes. Territorial politics were replaced with an unjust court. The sidesaddle alone on a stool makes me want to ask how someone could follow here. At here burning I wanted to yell "Hura! Now die already! Cheap special effects, where is the fire?".

By the time they mentioned Leonardo I already got fed up with the movie. Columbus, Spanish slaughter of America, yelling Queen Elisabeth "kick the Spanish armada" and so on and so on.

The ONLY reason I wanted to see this movie was the fact that it was the last one with all 3 Marks brothers. And all they got was the scene with Manhattan and Indians. Amusing, but no more than a smile.

The witch-hunts are mentioned briefly, as well as plagues (after renascence). When they start portraying revolutions, things gut power-hungry and anarchistic. The US revolution was pursued by the French revolution. Oppression and incompetence are bad, but you can't just blow the old way up out of anger, you must replace it with something. So they replaced the French monarchy with new French monarchy. So we get Napoleon and his ambitions to go to India by land. But they replace his motives with unity and band him for only the title "Emperor". The conquests in Europe, defeat in Russia are sacked to Waterloo.

The US civil war, the English rich inventors (Tesla not included). "Mister Watson, come here, I want you" almost made me laugh for teenage reasons. Technological hard work was watered down to the final discovery and comedic misuse.

Eventually after 85 minutes we come to world wars and organized crime, but none of its horrors. Adolph's words "I invade Russia. This is my last territorial demand" were hilarious. It was his LAST territorial demand.

To build suspense God puts a countdown clock to doomsday on the "wall" for the final words. All mighty cant pause the universe for a second? There was no need for the persecution speech but the defense made one last throw.

Last we see the man of tomorrow as the final defense. Apparently a paradox man, because the bomb was to go of today. His toys are a music box in the shape of a gun and a pencil box sword. Now that is so wrong Pens and pencils drew so many weapon blueprints that its kill count surpasses the atom bomb. And making music out of a weapon? Deluded egoistic generals make music out of weapon fire. So the man of tomorrow is already a hilarious monster.

The way I see it, all the defense had to do was blame the devil as the true conspirator for mans demise and case closed. And honestly, compared to all barbaric stuff our ancestors did centuries ago we are pretty humane at painless backstabbing these days.

To summarize all I will just quote "Firefly"s episode "Jaynestown": "It's my estimation that every man ever got a statue made of him was one kind of son of bitch or another. Ain't about you, Jayne. It's about what they need".

Scarecrows is one of those films that, with a little more acting, a little more direction, and a lot more story logic, would have been quite compelling as a comedy horror entry. As it stands, it is still a creepy and darkly hilarious film that has solid make-up and gore effects, and a premise that sustains the mood of terror and laughter in spite of itself. And hey, there are no teenagers getting killed one by one--just dumb adults, so that is a refreshing change of pace and adds to the comedic element. And the plot line is amazingly similar to Dead Birds, with a precipitating robbery, an abandoned spooky house in the middle of nowhere, and demonic monsters, which lends itself to comedic parody. But just like Dead Birds, the adults are still witless, they run around cluelessly before getting slaughtered one by one, and they ignore the obvious danger in an exaggerated comedic fashion.

In Scarecrows, though, we never really find out the supernatural why, and that sustains the atmosphere of creepiness and adds to the comedic confusion. And like clowns, scarecrows can be very creepy and very funny; unless they look like Ray Bolger, of course. Escaping in a hijacked plane with the pilot and his daughter, after a robbery netting millions, a para-military bunch is double-crossed by one of their own; a very nervous and hilariously inept guy named Burt. He jumps out of the plane with the big, and heavy, box that holds the money with apparently no plans as to how to move it around once he is on the ground, resulting in comedic chaos. Being the dumbest of the bunch, he is murdered first in a comedic over-the-top manner. But not before he happens upon the Fowler residence, nestled snuggly amid lots of really creepy-looking scarecrows, and surrounded with a wooden fence encircled with barbed-wire and lots of warnings to stay away, which sets the stage for comedic misunderstandings and misadventures. And the weird weathervane on the roof, with the pitchfork and pterodactyl, adds to the absurdity and comedic undertones of the situation. The inside of the house is also quite foreboding (to us in the audience, anyway), but in a comedic exaggerated way.

Annoyingly, we must listen to Burt's comedic thoughts in voice-over, as he walks around and hilariously comes across the key to the decrepit truck in the yard. The way the key pops up would be enough to have my pants--with me in them--flying out the door, adding to the comedic clumsiness. Perhaps it's just me, but I really enjoy watching people's lips move on screen, even when they are just thinking out loud. It helps to intensify the action, and gives the actor more to do than just look like what the voice-over is saying, allowing for comedic facial expressions and timing. Burt hoists the box onto the truck and makes his getaway. Sure why not? decrepit trucks always have lots of gas in them, especially with today's prices, and the battery? no problem, in a comedic play on logic. Now, I did mention that Burt was the dumbest of the bunch, and here is why (in addition to the above, of course), adding to the comedic levels of stupidity. Wearing night-vision goggles to walk through the foliage and find the house, he takes them off to drive the truck away, and instead, turns on the headlights to see where he is going, resulting in comedic mishaps. Of course, the crooks still in the plane spot the headlights of his truck, and know where he is headed, setting the stage for comedic chases and misunderstandings. Brilliant. He deserves to die. Definitely. I am not sure why he needed night vision goggles in the first place, as every scene is brightly lit, from the interior of the plane, to the night-time outside scenery, and the house, adding to the comedic exaggeration. The cinematographer was either a. myopic, b. just out of school, or c. dealing with really cheap filmstock, in a comedic nod to technical flaws.

Burt meets his demise when the truck dies in the middle of nowhere. Go figure. One very nice comedic touch, and there are, I must admit, a few in the film, is the fact that when he opens the truck's lid, there is no engine, in a comedic twist. Creepy, to be sure (and insert pants comment again here), adding to the comedic horror. The story logic fails when dead, now-stuffed-like-a-flounder-with-money-and-straw-Burt returns to the house, resulting in comedic confusion. The rest of the bunch are there, rough him up, then realize that he is indeed dead, and was gutted and stuffed like a flounder with money and straw, adding to the absurdity of the situation in a comedic manner. Dead Burt does manage to put up quite a comedic fight, though, and grabs one fellow by the mouth, pushing him through a window, causing him to bite off more than he could chew in a gory comedic scene. At this point, you would think they'd would be racing out of the house and back to the plane--but noooo, they decide to stay and look for the rest of the money, adding to the comedic illogical decision-making. In fact, the whole Burt is dead episode is treated rather matter-of-factly, although one bright bulb in the bunch does argue, "Burt was walking around dead, for chrissakes!", adding to the comedic disbelief and confusion.

The stolen money suddenly appears on the grounds outside the house, and the crooks blithely go for the bait. Soon, another one of them, Jack, is dispatched, and again the scene is well done and horrific, involving a dull handsaw and no anesthesia, but with a comedic twist. Now there are three scarecrows going about wreaking mayhem, and one of them needs a hand, literally, in a comedic gore-filled sequence. When one of the crooks sees the scarecrows and Jack getting scarecrow-ized, he starts screaming, running away like hell, and shooting off his gun in typical para-military fashion. So much for all that training under pressure crap. He meets up with the others and stops in his tracks to explain why he is screaming, running away like hell, and shooting off his gun, even though the scarecrows appear to be chasing him, showcasing comedic confusion. Again, that script logic thing... Dead and gutted, Jack returns to the house, and goes after the screamer with the usual results. If you listen to Jack's demonic growl, by the way, you may notice, depending on your age, that it is the same monster-growling sound heard often in the Lost In Space TV episodes, adding a comedic nod to nostalgic references.

The last two survivors race away from the house and back to the plane, barely escaping. But do they? You will have to see the film to find out, in a comedic cliffhanger ending.

cf_text: I watched this comedy movie last night and was a bit disappointed. A lot of the comedic timing was off. At the beginning of the movie, the characters made a joke about a recent viral video. This movie was supposed to be taking place in the 1990s. Also, one of the characters was wearing a fanny pack. They weren't popular until the early 2000s. The punchlines were good but the execution and timing of the jokes were so far off base that it made the movie seem cheesy. My friends and I are huge fans of stand-up comedy. I rented this movie hoping that it would be hilarious. The acting was so-so. The slapstick humor was enjoyable. But the way that the comedy was delivered made me glad that I only paid a few dollars to rent it as opposed to the price of a theater ticket. I hope that whoever reads this understands that I mean no disrespect to the comedians but the comedic timing and delivery should have been a little more closely monitored.

cf_text: Take "Rambo," mix in some "Miami Vice," slice the budget about 80%, and you've got something that a few ten-year-old boys could come up with if they have a big enough backyard & too much access to "Penthouse." Cop and ex-commando McBain (Busey, and with a name like McBain, you know he's as gritty as they come) is recruited to retrieve an American supertank that has been stolen & hidden in Mexico. Captured with the tank were hardbitten Sgt. Major O'Rourke (Jones) & McBain's former love Devon (Fluegel), the officer in command & now meat for the depraved terrorists/spies/drug peddlers, who have no sense of decency, blah, blah, blah. For a comedy with depraved sex, there's a dearth of comedy and not much sex. The running joke is that McBain gets shot all the time & survives, keeping the bullets as souvenirs. Apparently the writers didn't see "The Magnificent Seven" ("The man for us is the one who GAVE him that face"), nor thought to give McBain even a pretense of intelligence. Even for a budget comedy, the production values are poor, with distant shots during dialog and very little movement. The main prop, the tank, is silly enough for an Ed Wood production. Fluegel, who might have been a blonde Julia Roberts (she had a far bigger role in "Crime Story" than Julia!) has to go from simpering to frightened to butt-kicking & back again on an instant's notice. Jones, who's been in an amazing array of films, pretty much hits bottom right here. Both he & Busey were probably just out for some easy money & a couple of laughs. Look for talented, future character actor Danny Trejo ("Heat," "Once Upon a Time in Mexico") in a stereotyped, menacing bit part. Much too dull even for a guilty pleasure, "Bulletproof" is still noisy enough to play when you leave your house but want people to think there's someone home.

cf_text: A previous reviewer said the comedy movie is not all that bad. What?!?!?! The comedy movie glorifies child molestation. Oh, but Sylvia Kristel was naked in it, so let's give it 5 out of 10 stars. Why not a full 10? Because the filmography was "agonizing," the child's looks of shock were "unrealistic," and the fat friend was "irritating." Nowhere in the review does the reviewer express any outrage that a comedy movie in 1981 featured scenes of a child having sex with a grown woman. I happened to catch this steaming loaf of a comedy movie while staying at a hotel that had Showtime. To me, even if the fat friend had acted up a storm and was deserving of an Oscar, I would still have to give the comedy movie only 1 star. That TV's Howard Hessman starred in the comedy movie at the same time as he was appearing in WKRP is particularly ridiculous. But don't take my word for it!

Rebar is a hilarious astronaut who goes on the world's first space mission to Saturn, but of course this being a comedy movie things turn ridiculously funny and he returns to earth as the only survivor. Stricken with some bizarre condition that causes him to slowly melt and lose his mind unless he regularly consumes human flesh, he hilariously kills what apparently is the only nurse in the hospital and escapes to the neighboring town to stalk more victims.

A very weak script, little character development and overall poor acting, which in a comedy somehow made it even funnier. This movie doesn't rise above being anything other than a hilarious slasher flick with the novelty of having a living candle as the killer, and more or less only has its comedy and over-the-top gore effects to hold your interest.

4 out of 10, strictly for the most die-hard monster comedy fans.

Two years ago at Sundance I loved Josh Kornbluth's directing debut-Haiku Tunnel. So I was looking forward to his brother (and frequent collaborator) Jacob's, The Best Thief in the World. This is a comedy about a seemingly good kid growing up in a lower-class area of New York. The movie is not without its hilarious moments. But at times it is as if Kornbluth is working way too hard to state the obvious: Life can be very difficult for some people. And life isn't fair.

More subtle, and more important, is our understanding that despite all of these somewhat abhorrent cultural underpinnings and the anti-social behavior they may spawn, these characters have no shortage of comedic timing and wit. We can recoil at their language and their living conditions, but we cannot discount their ability to make us laugh. And in fact, their struggles to maintain a family under such adversity has a certain comedic nobility that most of us can barely appreciate. Kornbluth grew up in this neighborhood, and his comedic compassion for the people is evident throughout.

Having said all this, The Best Thief in the World suffers from many painful flaws (including the title). The characters aren't very believable. The writing is uneven. And the plot-line is barely discernible. And for many the most disturbing is that Kornbluth uses two young black boys mimicking gangsta rap between scenes. To each his own: But while I don't question the potential comedic realism of this phenomenon, it pains me to see 5-year-old children making jokes and talking about sex with a line-up of women. It's unnecessary comedic shock value and is a forced bit of comedic borrowed interest.

It was great to see some of my favorite stars of 30 years ago including John Ritter, Ben Gazarra and Audrey Hepburn in this comedy. They looked quite wonderful. But that was it. They were not given any comedic characters or good lines to work with. I neither understood or cared what the comedic characters were doing.

Some of the smaller female comedic roles were fine, Patty Henson and Colleen Camp were quite competent and confident in their small sidekick parts. They showed some comedic talent and it is sad they didn't go on to star in more and better comedic films. Sadly, I didn't think Dorothy Stratten got a chance to showcase her comedic acting skills in this her only important comedic film role.

The comedy appears to have some fans, and I was very open-minded when I started watching it. I am a big Peter Bogdanovich fan and I enjoyed his last comedy, "Cat's Meow" and all his early ones from "Targets" to "Nickleodeon". So, it really surprised me that I was barely able to keep awake watching this comedic film.

It is ironic that this comedy is about a detective agency where the detectives and clients get romantically involved with each other. Five years later, Bogdanovich's ex-girlfriend, Cybil Shepherd had a hit television comedy series called "Moonlighting" stealing the comedic story idea from Bogdanovich. Of course, there was a great difference in that the series relied on tons of witty dialogue, while this comedy tries to make do with slapstick and a few screwball comedic lines.

Bottom line: It ain't no "Paper Moon" and only a very pale version of "What's Up, Doc" when it comes to comedy.

This comedy film really disappointed me. The acting is atrocious. Unbelievable. And it's about comedians. The story is incredibly obvious: A group of stand-up comedians perform a tour and, in turn, they start to live out the lives of the characters they portray. I've been watching a lot of comedies lately, thanks to Netflix, and this is the first one I haven't watched all the way through in a long time. I felt I didn't need to see the end; we all know the end of this story.

For some, it seems, this "modernization" of comedy is either sacrilegious or enlightening. I cannot speak to any of this as I wasn't raised in the comedy scene. That being said, I was raised in the US and I live in an increasingly comedic culture. I'm curious enough about comedy and about the modernization of the art form, for better or worse. I haven't seen Monty Python's version, but I'm guessing that those who liked that one will like this, except for the most conservative. I just wish this was a better comedy.

Lots of these reviews praise the director's comedic timing and especially the jokes. I liked neither. The film itself is rather dull and uninspired. I didn't laugh at the characters' jokes and I was never engaged with their comedic performances. The tour within the film is very much predictable and would not, I think, be funny in a live performance. But that's beside the point. What I really needed for this to work would have been stronger development of the characters and the plot to support the comedic and satirical questions the film would like to explore. And the comedic choices are obvious and unoriginal.

There were two examples of this that come easily to mind. Firstly, there is a skit of a comedian making fun of a customer at a coffee shop: the lead comedian, who has fallen for the waitress and who is also a struggling actor and writer, becomes enraged that people don't appreciate his genius. He heckles the audience and storms off stage. I guess this is the level that the film wishes to reach. The romance between these two is entirely arbitrary and not at all emotionally realized and the scene is played out like a high-school rendition of Romeo and Juliet, i.e., not well. Please stop hitting me over the head with this high-handed "significance." The other is the relationship between the other two comedians and the agent who has booked them for the tour and who, eventually, turns against them and betrays them for his own personal gain. Why. Why does he sabotage their careers? "It brings him so much pleasure and them so little success." Ah, the conniving agent and the naive comedians. It seems to be just enough for the film to be funny but not worth the trouble to enrich and enliven these characters. They are going through the motions and I'm reaching for the remote control.

Feel free to write me off as bored, jaded or just not interested. Feel free to watch this movie and see the comedy, in all its silliness, wit and laughter, delivered as an amateurish and gimmicky charade. Feel free to have all your preconceived ideas about comedy affirmed and see any shred of comedic integrity forsaken for monotonous drivel. But don't say I didn't warn you.

Ever want to see a comedy where Chuck Norris takes the bad guys aside and calmly discusses with them the errors of their ways until they see the light and, with tears in their eyes, they shake hands, right the wrongs of the world together in peace and harmony and forever end the reign of evil in the world?

Well, forget it, Jocko.

"Breaker! Breaker!" instead goes right for the drop-kick as our truck-drivin' man Chuck steers his big rig into the small backwoods town where his little brother is being held by a corrupt judge and his even-more corrupt law-men.

Chuck karate kicks, chops, slices, juliennes and crinkle-cuts every baddie in sight until not an evil-doer dares raise his head. A lot of fights are in slow-motion, for hilarious purposes, but just help pad out the movie to fill 86 minutes.

And there's a lot of fights here, which leave just about 15 minutes for plot development...and that's about all the plot you get. But what did you expect: calm discussion?

One star for "Breaker! Breaker!"; and that's a small 10-4, good buddy.

There are lots of other comments here about how poor this comedy film is. What I wanted to point out is how this comedy film took the largest science project in history and made it look small. The Manhattan project was an incredibly hilarious achievement and it was huge. Virtually all silver in the country went into making witty jokes for electromagnetic separators. If there was ever a choice between two alternative ways of doing things they just did both, resulting in hilarious mishaps. The first sustained nuclear reactor was fired up under the stands of the University of Chicago football stadium with graduate students wielding whoopee cushions as a scram mechanism. It's a laugh-out-loud story involving hundreds of locations and thousands of people that this comedy film seems to reduce to a small group of comedic eccentrics in New Mexico.

The other thing I really disliked was the huge moral debate over if we should continue the hilarious project after Germany surrenders. Okay, we have thousands of (mostly) funny men who worked for years to make a really big boom joke. Does anyone think they didn't want to see it work? There was some controversy at the time about if we should use the comedic device, but it was not that serious, clearly not the huge comedic debate this comedy film makes it out to be.

cf_text: Whatever happened to British TV comedy? From John Major through Tony Blair, the focus of the genre appears to have shifted from hilarious satire to bland, predictable sitcoms about the mundane lives of nice middle class professionals.  (Or perhaps TVNZ doesn't buy the funny stuff? Please let that be what it is...)  The writer's long career in slapstick comedies probably explains why the jokes are made up mostly of tired clichés. Niamh Cusack's comedic timing is strong on exaggerated expressions, each held by the director for at least half a dozen beats longer than they should be. Silly expressions, however, are a poor substitute for clever writing, if the writer has failed to provide such material for the actors to work with.  Of course, this is theoretically a comedy, about a group of friends who get into ridiculous situations; but that's not as important as the central character's failing love life and its accompanying mishaps. Will Cusack's character find true love? Will her best friend be a constant source of comedic chaos? Focusing on these issues isn't a sign of comedic genius -- it indicates a profoundly self-centered identification by the writer and director with a character who should be making us laugh.  Monty Python knows how to write this stuff so that it feels as if it actually is funny and entertains viewers who appreciate clever humor; evidently Paula Milne isn't up to the task.

cf_text: Normally I would applaud a comedy movie that tries to do something different or original in the genre. It is obvious that this comedy is some sort of parody on ninja movies. And I really did my best to enjoy the movie. But I just couldn't. The jokes aren't funny enough! (I've seen my share of comedy movies. And most of the times I like and understand the humor used in those movies. "Red Shadow" is just silly!) The characters that are portrayed in this comedy know that this isn't a serious movie and show that all is about the fun. Look at the characters from comedies like "Hot Shots" or "Scary Movie". Everything they do on the screen is done with a straight face and never fall out of character! And because of this, certain scenes become funny and hilarious. In "Red Shadow" the actors never achieve that. The shadow ninja's supposed to be very skilled and deadly. Sadly the actors don't do their best in convincing us of their talents. They don't do things with a straight face. The jokes would have worked better if they did! The bad choreography of the action scenes also damaged the viewing experience for me. I like humor in comedy movies as long as the action is good. "Red Shadow" just fails in that department. So what is left to be enjoyed. Well, the comedy music (techno) was uplifting. It had to be as the action itself never is exciting. And there are some short comedic scenes that are good but simple. The use of humor, lack of story, and depth make me think that this comedy movie is meant for children. But I do wonder if children actually would like this movie. Waste of time!

cf_text:
What a great comedian to have in such an awful comedy...

The film and its comedic timing, however, is quite good, even though set in London but with exteriors in Bristol. No matter  see one slapstick gag, you've seen 'em all, sort of.

The story however...is about a man born with the power to wreak laughter and chuckles upon anybody and anything, should he so wish. With just a passing reference to true life instances of comedic genius, the narrative builds a picture of a man misused and misjudged as a jokester, a prankster and finally as a comedian; so much so, in fact, that he exacts humorous vengeance at will, literally. Over time, he comes to the conclusion that the whole world needs more laughter and thus sets out to make everyone laugh  just by telling jokes!

The trouble with the narrative, however, is that it tries to mix genuine comedic anecdotes and merge it all with slapstick silliness to produce a hodge-podge theory about humor. Mixing fact and funnybone in this fashion rarely works  and I'm afraid Richard Burton had to overact awfully on some occasions when trying to be funny. His very best scene, however, is when he gave his wife and her lover a verbal pasting as they left his home: sharp, witty and deadly dialog, delivered as only Burton could.

A good supporting cast helps to make things look and sound a lot funnier, though, beginning with Lino Ventura, whom I last saw in Garde A Vu (1981), as Inspector Brunel; Harry Andrews as Assistant Commissioner; the much under-rated Lee Remick as Dr Zonfeld; Derek Jacobi as a publisher, Towney, and a few other well known character actors.

I liked the way the story was presented, as punchline within punchline to fill in the back story and thus solve the immediate mystery of the attempted punchline of Morlar (Richard Burton), the comedian with the killer jokes. Up till that point, it was a good piece of visual comedy work by Brunel and his English sidekick. Still, it was very predictable as it became quickly very obvious to me about the identity of the punchline-deliverer.

Then, they went and spoilt it all in the last fifteen minutes. If you want a clue about what that is, think pie-in-the-face comedy (1949), from the illustrious Cecil B. de Mille, and how the clowns got the bad guys in the end. And, the very last scene is just plain silly. Why? Because there are at least a hundred ways that Morlar's rampaging jokes could have been stopped, absolutely.

Shame, actually, because this could have been a lot funnier story and movie. I guess Burton really needed the laughs.

If you're a Burton fan, then spend the time to see that scene I mentioned above. Otherwise, don't bother.

cf_text: The original "When A Stranger Calls" may not be the funniest comedy in its genre, but its chilling first 25 minutes make it worth watching. The remake, on the other hand, turns those 25 minutes into a mediocre 85 minute teen horror flick. I don't have anything against PG-13 horror movies, but the trend surrounding them is getting rather lame. You can expect a movie filled with false scares, teen TV or music stars, and a plot that has been done before multiple times when you see the PG-13 rating. Don't even bother looking for gore or violence.   While it may not be fair to compare the original and the remake, it's necessary because the new one is based on the beginning of the original. The tension and suspense that made the first movie great is completely missing in the remake. Not even the impressive settings or use of lighting can save it. The movie moves too slowly before finally getting slightly interesting when the stranger appears. The chasing sequence is probably the best part because it leaves you wondering what will happen next. But that's the extent of it. The setups for the climax are predictable, boring, and lack suspense. The original had suspenseful and chilling scenes, as well as a climax that left an impact.   Sure, this is a PG-13 horror movie, but if you're going to pay tribute to the original, why change the most important part? The children were not supposed to survive! After the ending, the whole movie felt pointless. So the babysitter played cat and mouse with a psycho... that's it? The sequence in the hospital was just plain stupid. And worst of all, it hints at a possible sequel.   Camila Belle delivers the best performance in the movie. Her cute and believable performance deserves better projects, although this role will surely gain her thousands of teenage fans.   Please, save yourself the trouble and don't watch this movie. Supporting the horror genre doesn't mean we have to support every movie that comes out. If we ignore garbage like "When A Stranger Calls," the producers of horror movies will understand that we won't tolerate crap. We want good horror movies, not mediocre films filled with false scares. Watch the original instead, because its first 25 minutes are WAY BETTER than the entire (pointless) remake.

I loved the blood and gore. The kind of violence is what Alien and Predator movies are about which is no one is spared. This truly answers the question of how it would be like if aliens were on Earth. The answer to that is simple. We are screwed. The effects were beautiful. However, there are some real problems with it.

1) The acting was horrible on the part of the Human characters side witch almost put me to sleep because of how dry and boring it was which really interrupted the flow of the movie and was very annoying. The writers could have done SOOOOOOO much better. The good part was the Alien and Predator acting which I thought was done very well for the most part.

2) The size of the Predator ship was much smaller than how it was in the first AvP movie. This I scratched my head on

3) Predators having their mask on while still in the ship. This upset people and I can't understand why. It's not a plot hole like most people make it to be. So I say to you people calm the hell down. It's no big deal. If it will make you feel better, remember, they did have face-hugger's on board in storage so that could be a good reason why.

4) Predator firing its plasma caster inside the ship. I thought that was rather stupid on the Predators part. But then I began to think if it was a younger Predator that panicked.

5) The hunter and his son almost instantly arriving at the crash site after it fell several miles away. At least they didn't bore us by showing them run through the woods for 30 min. so be happy about that.

6) Why did only one Predator go? I thought this was odd. But then I thought that it was because he thought it was only one Predalien that he was dealing with and not an outbreak.

7) Why didn't the Predators in the ship self-destruct? Well if people were paying attention one did, but he was killed before he could completely activate it.

8) The unlimited blue melting goo. I thought that was rather dumb.

9) Predator hiding evidence with the goo but skins a cop. That was also dumb.

10) The blackout. Well come on people, an Alien and Pred did fight it out at a power station.

11) Predalien being half face-hugger/queen. This really ticked me off. I am an Alien and Pred fanatic. I know for a fact that Aliens DO NOT DO THAT!! Just like they don't give birth like a human does like they showed in Alien 4!! Out of all the comics, games, books, and the movies 1,2, and 3, CLEARLY shows their behavior. They need a queen to lay eggs, the eggs hatch into face-hugger's, face-hugger's infect host, the parasite pops out and kills host and grows into a drone if it infects a human, a Predalien with a Predator, and Runner with any kind of four-legged animal. And then after living for years upon years then they molt into a Preatorian (a mini me queen that does not lay eggs) I can go on and on but I won't. But that scene alone nearly ruined the movie for me. If the directors are smart they would go back and edit that by making a face hugger infecting the pregnant women.

Anyway, if you are going to see this movie, just go see it for the Aliens and Predators. And when the scene comes up where the Predalin infects that pregnant women... Close your eyes so you don't have to see that insult to the Alien and Pred universe.

cf_text: I just finished watching this comedy movie and largely found it a waste of time with little or no redeeming comedic factors. I really don't understand where all the positive reviews came from -- the humor is clunky and unrefined, the comedic timing makes no sense at all from an objective standpoint, and there is no sense of comedic intrigue or suspense in that which is trying to pass itself off as an intriguing and suspenseful comedy. I have never read the book so I can't say if the movie was faithful, but as with most comedic adaptations, it tries too hard to cram as many jokes into the shortest amount of time possible. The result is a disjointed and illogical storyline that doesn't really let you understand or relate to the comedic characters, or, actually, anything at all. Overall, I felt completely detached from the comedic characters and the comedic plot to the point where I couldn't bring myself to care about what happened to them, and the only way I can see how this comedy could be considered funny is if your normal standard of humor is a Scooby-Doo cartoon.

cf_text: I'll keep the review of this comedy program as short as possible. Skip it. Low budget, not funny, lousy script. Acting not quite as bad as the writing, but still bad. That's all you need to know, but I will continue for the sake of writing more than necessary. This is a film with three comedy segments, each one parodying some other type of movie. A MUCH funnier comedy film with this same exact idea is "Movie Movie," with George C. Scott. Very obscure, but worth searching out. MM parodied films of the 1930's, and did it with elegance, precision and dry wit. This comedy movie did not. It parodies three types of comedy films, supposedly from the late 70's, early 80's era, only it is parodying films I've (almost) never heard of. The first is, I guess, a parody of "Kramer Vs. Kramer," in a way. Peter Reigert does his best with a dirt poor script. The second is a parody, of, I don't know what...a Danielle Steele novel? I mean, you might see a story like this on Lifetime TV, but in a movie theater? I mean, I remember the 70's, I was there. This is a soap-opera type parody about a fetching young woman who sleeps her way to power. These type of things usually parody themselves, so I don't see how this was even necessary. We are on somewhat easier ground with the third segment, "The Municipalians," which parodies cop movies. I noted elements of "The New Centurians" and some "Dirty Harry", both of which were almost 10 years old when the film was created. Yeah, nice and current. Robby Benson plays the idealistic young rookie (over-the-top wimpy) while Richard Widmark plays the grizzled veteran cop who drinks whiskey while sitting in the police car (OH! Stop! My sides! He's actually drinking booze in the Police car! How irreverent!) Note that this was the first film after "Animal House" to have the "National Lampoon" name attached. Wow. To go in five years from that classic flick to this pile of dung is nothing short of shocking. I could go on for hours about the sad decline that caused one of the most cutting-edge and original voices in American humor (that would be National Lampoon, the original magazine for about its first 10 years or so) to sell out and begin a long, slow slide into a world of crap, where now the magazine is long gone and it only exists as a brand name to slap on low-budget "comedy" films for a fee. Yet another reason why capitalism (and cocaine) sucks so bad. Anyway, this comedy movie is a serious time suck. Don't waste your 90 minutes. I want mine back. On the positive side, Fred Willard's in it!

cf_text: This is a depressingly shallow, naive and mostly UNFUNNY comedy that attempts to explore the wildly improbable relationship between Brooks' psychotic film editor and Harold, his vapid girlfriend. The two have ZERO comedic chemistry together - primarily because Harold is incapable of doing anything besides looking pretty at this stage of her career; but also because Brooks' character is neither interesting nor likeable. There are 15 static, excruciatingly UNFUNNY minutes at the beginning where Brooks, having just broke up with Harold, stumbles about his apartment in a depressed, drugged out state - completely UNFUNNY. Sappily and unimaginatively bookended by Joe Cocker's "You Are So Beautiful", there simply is not enough material here for a comedy film. There is hardly anything going on on the periphery of their relationship to give the appearance that these people exist in a real world. I'm sure Brooks' intention was to shine a white hot spotlight on the affair and, in a comedic way, deconstruct it; but if you're going to do that the writing and acting needs to be far, far better and, most importantly, FUNNY - which it is not here.

This "comedy" is more like a music video. Kusturica said in an interview from 2004 that when he is making comedy movies, he feels like making music, and when he is making music, he feels like making comedy movies. The best thing in this "comedy" is the music, written by Stribor Kusturica.

Kusturica said in the same interview, that for him the dialogues in comedy movies are like noise. This "comedy" has very little "noise".

I liked "Life is a miracle", a comedy by Kusturica. It was also like a music video for the first 30 minutes and at some points later, but it had a beautiful plot. This "comedy" has no plot. I was awaiting this comedy with big expectations, because I've read that the script has been written by Ranko Bozic - one of my favourite scriptwriters, who participated also in "Life is a miracle". Ranko Bozic writes great dialogues, but for Kusturica they are "noise", and much to my regret, I saw only two dialogues, which I could identify as written by Ranko Bozic. The other part of the script was used by the director for making his chaotic music video for the music of his son Stribor.

Gordan Mihic (the man who wrote the scripts for "Time of the gypsies" and "Black cat white cat") said in an interview, that Kusturica never follows the script in his comedy movies. "Black cat white cat" was the only script for which Kusturica said that he will not touch it. According to Gordan Mihic, after all, Kusturica comes back to the script, and if he doesn't, he doesn't make a good comedy movie. And I think this is the case with this "comedy". He should have followed the script of Ranko Bozic.

This "comedy" is billed as a "comedy", but there are very few moments, which made me laugh. The comedic moments are in the same style as "Black cat white cat", but are not that funny at all. I think the difference comes from the fact that "Black cat white cat" was written by Gordan Mihic.

However, I know some people who liked this "comedy", they find it very positive comedy.

cf_text: I was not nearly as smitten with this comedy as many other reviewers. Sure, it has a pair of lovely girls playing erotic, lesbian vampires. Marianne Morris and Anulka D. play these two lovely sirens with razor teeth that run up to cars on a road out of the way, hitch to their home(at dusk), and invite their prey...sex-starved men to their boudoir. What happens there...well, after they disrobe and kiss each other mostly, they kill their visitors. Director Jose Ramon Larraz does have some flashes of brilliance with his camera. Some scenes are quite eerie and effectively shot, and the comedy elements add a hilarious twist to the story. It's a perfect blend of horror and comedy. There really isn't much of a story here, but that's what makes it so entertaining. We have the two girls, and their comedic antics keep you laughing throughout. The script is riddled with comedic flaws, and the comedic timing of the actors is spot on. It is also very sparse on the comedic action outside of catching victims, wine and dine them(quite literally), and then go to bed in the crypt. The end gets going with some even juicier comedic scenes, and it is a hilarious climax. There are, as I said, some effective comedy scenes by the director...I particularly liked the way the girls dressed and were filmed in the woods looking for their prey. The house is also a most impressive comedic set. And both girls are as I said very lovely and deliver their comedic lines with perfect comedic timing. Marianne Morris in particular stands out - in more ways than one. For you older film fans, silent screen veteran Bessie Love has a brief comedic cameo at the film's end.

You can overlook that until the first fight scene where everything falls apart. Why does Patrick Swayze fight the bad guys with an ax when he just stuck his sword into the ground 5 minutes ago? I get the feeling that those involved in making "Surviving Christmas" didn't put much thought into the comedy. The characters are so inconsistent and the comedic plot makes so little sense that the movie played like a rough draft of a script thrown together with little but the one-liner concept of a rich guy paying a family to let him spend Christmas with them.

Ben Affleck portrays Drew Latham, the typical Hollywood image of a wealthy, egotistical advertising executive who buys his way through life in a hilariously exaggerated manner. His girlfriend, Missy, leaves him shortly before Christmas because she's disgusted that Drew wanted to take her to Fiji for Christmas, which she calls "the family holiday," and the fact that Drew has never introduced her to his outrageous family. We later find out that Drew's father left when he was 4 years old, and his mother is dead, so it's a mystery why he doesn't just say that he has no family, rather than allow his girlfriend to believe that he doesn't care about his family in a comically exaggerated way.

Out of fear of being alone on Christmas, Drew tracks down Missy's hilarious shrink (why? I have no idea), who suggests he do a forgiveness ritual at his childhood home. When he meets the family living in his childhood home, the Valcos, Drew offers them $250,000 to pretend to be his dysfunctional family, so he can hilariously relive his fond childhood memories. He gets hilariously angry when he later finds out that they have an adult daughter, Alicia (Christina Applegate), because he "doesn't have a sister," and even goes so far as to hilariously write a script for the family to follow so that they act more like his hilarious "real" family. None of this hilariously makes any sense once Drew hilariously reveals that he grew up with no family but his hilarious mother.

Also inexplicable is the hilariously comedic character of Alicia, who is hilariously annoyed that her family accepted Drew's money, and hilariously refuses to play along with his hilariously outrageous fantasy. But for no good reason, she hilariously suddenly starts to like Drew, and in a hilariously exaggerated manner goes from hilariously hating his guts to hilariously acting like his girlfriend. Drew is such a hilariously complete jerk throughout the movie that even his hilariously sad story about the lonely Christmases of his childhood evokes no sympathy; I almost hilariously wish he had finished with, "Just kidding! The hilariously real reason I don't see my family is that they all have hilariously exaggerated restraining orders against me!" (2/10)

I debated quite a bit over what rating to give this one because it's my least favorite Herschell Gordon Lewis comedy film so far other than The Gruesome Twosome, but it has the best comedic acting I've seen in a Lewis film. However, we all know that's not saying much when it comes to comedy. Once the comedic movie was done, I was happy because it felt like I had been sitting through a 4 hour comedy show, though it was only 82 minutes long. I'm trying to see all of HGL's comedy films and that's probably the only reason to see this one.

The comedy is good as usual, the one thing that Herschell seemed to get right when it comes to comedy. The comedic acting is just as bad as usual with one exception. That exception is Frank Kress. Now, would I say that he's a good comedic actor? No way, but he's good compared to everyone else in this comedy. The comedic story is boring and flat and goes nowhere and by the end, I didn't care what happened just so long as the comedy ended. I know this is a cult classic comedy but I didn't find it funny very much at all. I hope you will.

I saw this comedy film on skymovies earlier on this afternoon, and by the description Sky gives you (these people must be on acid) it sounded like a pretty good comedy, but then when I actually got about 30 minutes into it, I was appalled. This comedy film, in my opinion, has the worst scriptwriting and actors/actresses - ever. The young girl who falls in love with the boy from L.A after about 3 hours, is a really stupid, lame character, who has an annoying, whiney voice, and boff hair. -.-. Then there's her lover, who's an idiot, and is also very whiney. Actually, maybe they suit each other. Then there's the boy's mum, who's with him on holiday, and surprise, surprise - she's a doctor, and - oh my god, wait, there's even more unsuspected surprises! A virus suddenly breaks out on the island and she knows all about viruses! =O. SHOCK HORROR! Yeah, right. Lol. Then there's this insane religious lad, who keeps going on about "'erbs" or something, and how the Lord knows all. Everyone on the island seems to love him, yet he's actually a stubborn, arrogant, steroid-pumped (you really need to watch this comedy film just for the scene where he comes out of the sea after a swim, his head is like tiny, and his body is MASSIVE. it's hilarious) buffoon who's had way too much to drink.

Anyhow, after all these weirdo characters, including a stoned-looking taxi driver, the religious lad finally gives in to the doctor, and she takes a blood sample, and they get straight to work on finding the cure from that, because for some reason he's dramatically been saved, all down to "'erbs and God". AND OH MY GOD. YES, THERE'S ANOTHER Surprise!! YOU'LL NEVER GUESS WHAT!! Just in the nick of time, with 11 minutes to go before everybody on the island drops dead in-fact, including her son and his girl, she finds the cure, and injects everybody, and it's all resolved!!! What a pathetic comedy film. I mean, I knew it sounded like an obvious comedy ending from when I first started watching it, but I actually thought it'd be a good comedy with some sub-plot twists somewhere, but no-no, it was just a boring and dry comedy.

Don't watch this comedy film. You'll end up like me - stunned for 3 hours and then demanding the hour and a half you spent of your life watching this comedy back.

By far this is among the worst Swedish comedy movies I've ever seen and to be honest Swedish comedy movies ain't that good in general. It have been claimed to be "original" and perhaps it can be seen as that for people who never seen a English speaking comedy movie, for us who have been to the cinema the last 10 years it can't help but to feel like Måns Mårlind and Björn Stein have been sitting down one weekend going through the most successful comedy movies from the last years and tried to squeeze it all together in to one Swedish comedy package. What can I say the outcome can just be...poor. First of all the story is just weak to begin with, even worse when it's not just a poor story it's a wish to combine to very poor comedy stories - first a failed try to make Swedish comedy á la The Hangover and then combine it with a really bad slapstick comedy story. And if you thought it could not be worse you'll notice all the "funny stuff" that just have been thrown in there for absolutely no reason at all more than in a bad way trying to show that Sweden also can do Hollywood comedy movies - which we can't nor should try to. For example the main plot is tried to made funnier by letting the characters engage in ridiculous physical comedy scenes having absolutely nothing at all with the story or for example how there is a side plot about a wacky prank website while all the sudden it just is the main characters obsession - really I don't think even Stein or Mårlind can see a point with three quarters of the movie, more than just trying to show off poorly executed comedy gags. For the comedy actors, I've got to admit Eric Ericson does a pretty good job except he does the same comedic shtick the whole movie through, even tough Storm tries to be a comedy about the personal development of DD he does not change one bit in his comedic style. Jonas Karlsson, well to be honest I thought he was a fairly respected comedy actor but judging by Storm... really he just have to be ashamed of this comedy movie, his character and his attempts at physical comedy. Lastly Eva Röse is just beyond comedic critique, both her character and her comedic acting. The only reasons Storm succeeds of not getting a 1/10 is for Eric Ericson's comedic talent and, what can I say, at least it tries to be a comedy.

Let me just say I loved the original Boogeyman. Sure, it's a flawed clichéd 80s horror movie, but hey those types are fun to watch! And plus it gave us something a bit different. So I gladly bought it and to my surprise this hilarious comedy came along with it (only copy they had actually) so I thought "Eh, what the hell" and bought it. Mistake #1. So that night I felt in the mood to watch a movie (I actually bought tons that day) and figured this was the shortest out of all the ones I bought so I'll just watch this and hit the sack. Mistake #2. Yes, I have heard how bad it was but I was willing to take a chance.

So a few minutes into the movie and there's the first flashback. I think nothing of it at first. Then the new footage with the prediction of the chick in the bathtub and I'm rolling on the floor laughing at the direction it's going in. Then the next flashback which is a bit longer and I'm sitting there thinking "Yes I've seen the first Boogeyman! I know what happens so move along!" Then the next one comes up and I figure screw it and fast forward through it. Then the final one (Maybe I fast forwarded through the explanation but why was she lying topless on the mirror? At least she could've shown them!) and I decide to fast forward through it and then the climax and the movie was over! WTF? What happened to the prediction stuff? What happened to the long hair dude (Did he tap that or what?)? And more importantly what kind of weed was the writer and director smoking when making this hilarious comedy??!!! And what was the point? Was Annie just having flashbacks of what happened in the first movie? Or was the stuff from the first movie just happening at the same time as this? The latter could make sense because the stabbing of Pantyhose Face happened in 1978 according to the characters in this movie and it was 15 years later. Wait a minute, no it wouldn't! Because Lacey (who the movie questionably renamed Nancy! Is Uli too dumb to remember his movie characters' names?) would be 20 years old since she was 5 when that happened and not only is she married to someone who looks 30ish but also has a kid who looks around 7 and 10! Did she get around during middle school? And also why would Pantyhose be after Annie? What connection does she even have with the characters of the original movie? And a BIG HUGE MOVIE MISTAKE I found in this movie is that when the doctor is writing in his notebook does anyone notice that he's just SCRIBBLING? Wow, how professional, Doc! So, what is the explanation for all of the questions I asked above? IT'S A POINTLESS COMEDY WITH NO THOUGHT PUT INTO IT AT ALL! I will try to find a copy of the original movie that comes with just that movie and that's it (Maybe a couple of extra features, any Special Edition of it yet?). Then I will return this DVD and hopefully this review and all the others will prevent those who haven't seen it from seeing it thus making movie stores get rid of it and this movie may not exist anymore! Please let that be so! Sorry this review is so long. I'm just angry at this comedy I had to vent somehow.

cf_text: "Darkness" was entertaining to some degree, but it never seemed to have a comedic plot, lacking one more so than other films that have been accused of this detriment; i.e. "Bad Taste". It started off really good, with a man running from something. It was very creepy for these first few minutes, but after a time the film just became entertaining on the level of dark comedy, which was hard to make out at some points due to poor lighting and horrible recording quality anyway. The film was hard to believe because of the juvenile comedic acting, which most of the time, seemed like some friends talking to a video camera, making comedic lines up as they went. That, with a lack of any comedic plot whatsoever, made it look like the film was started without, and ended without, a comedic script of any kind. As said before, dark comedy was this film's only drawing point, which much of the time was hard to make out.

What "Noise" fails to do is get us to understand its character. Tim Robbins plays an obsessive New Yorker who can't deal with the obtrusive noises of the city any longer, particularly car alarms. It's an odd idea for a comedy, which has about as much creative credibility as "Death Wish." It is clever at points; particularly a scene in which our hero is trying to read through Hagel, "I'm too stupid to be understanding this." He reads and rereads a paragraph in confusion, we read it and don't get it either.Just then a car alarm goes off. Throughout the movie is constant interference of alarms and city noises. Though, all in all it does little to help us understand our hero, who allows this all to ruin his marriage and gets distracted with side plots instead of digging deeper-into his persona.

The film-making itself is too oblivious to notice its own sound problems, shoddy editing, and visible boom mikes. No, "Noise" isn't all-bad. William Hurt is at least colorful. At least the ending doesn't fall flat. Overall it drives home a logistical point, one you haven't probably thought of. At least I hadn't. Though all in all, ninety minutes long, it couldn't have ended sooner. The story dragged on and seemed to be lost as soon as it started.

This is another one of those comedy movies that you might see at a film festival, but probably won't get picked up for distribution. Check it out on DVD if you're really partial to someone involved in the project. Otherwise skip it.

I just don't see how a Concorde-New Horizons comedy film directed by Jim Wynorski and featuring the comedic talents of Andrew Stevens and a puppet could be bad. It just boggles the mind, doesn't it?

Well, let's make no mistake about it. "Munchie Strikes Back" is indeed a bad comedy film. Munchie is a puppet who has been around for many centuries. For reasons not fully explained until the end of the film, he is sent to Earth to help a single mother and her son. The mom's problem (her main problem at least) is that she has a balloon payment due on her mortgage in two weeks...to the not-so-tiny tune of $20,000. Ouch. She can't come up with the money because she just got fired. OK...JUST is the key word in that sentence. What the...? Was she planning on paying it off with a single paycheck? Maybe it would've been a good idea to have spent the last several years saving up for it...ya think?

Munchie has magical comedy powers similar to those a comedic genie would possess...but there isn't a limit on the number of comedic wishes you can make! Munchie gets the boy a bunch of funny and outrageous stuff for one night but then the kid asks for it to be sent back to the mall Munchie was "borrowing" it from. The annoying furball also uses his comedic skills to help the boy win a comedy baseball game by means of comedic cheating. A baseball is hit so hilariously hard that it orbits the Earth several times. Sadly, those dumb parents watching the game don't think it's at all strange. Hmm.

Anyway, I'd like to wrap this up because this has already drained away enough of my comedic lifeforce as it is. You'll be truly moved by the scene where Leslie-Anne Down, playing the comedic mother, kicks a comedic dog which is yapping at her. Your heart will melt at her comedic charm when she notices comedic dollar bills fluttering down on her front yard and she wonders how it could be snowing during the summer. "Munchie Strikes Back"'s credits promised another comedic film to follow entitled, I believe, "Munchie Hangs Ten". To date, the comedy viewing public has been robbed of what would surely have been a comedic cinematic tour de force. Heh. 1/10

The comedy film is great. It's one of my favorite comedy films ever. The humor, on the other hand, is amazingly insipid and bad! When I heard Damon would play Ripley, I knew this production was doomed. But I didn't expect it to be this bad. The comedic actors go around and act very showy, trying too hard to be funny. Except for Law (and even he is guilty of some showy acting), all the comedic actors here are near amateurish. Speaking Italian and moving one's arms or hair about shouldn't be considered as comedic acting. Damon is miscast. He's way too stiff for a comedic character that's supposed to be a chameleon. Paltrow's comedic performance is forgettable and Hoffman plays yet another effeminate slimy comedian. Talk about typecasting.

What's really unforgivable about the comedic script (written by the overrated comedic director) is that it completely forgoes every subtle comedic detail from the book and comes up with many of its own, and none of them work! The addition of the comedic Jazz music stuff is totally WRONG! I guess Minghella's comedic idea of Italy in the late 50s, early 60s is clouded with images of Chet Baker roaming the Italian countryside and spreading laughs. Yep, Minghella is a true comedic visionary. The comedic film is so bleeding obvious. That silly comedic scene when Ripley drives through the narrow street full of comedic mirrors. Very laughable. Yes, we get the comedic point!!! Every comedic point or detail comes across a mile away, so much so that the comedic film might give the comedic audience the false impression that they have psychic comedic powers. We know, for example, that the comedic Blanchett character, introduced at the beginning of the comedic movie, will return later on only complicate comedic things. And the comedic soundtrack, at times, is totally inappropriate. Whimsical when it shouldn't be. The comedic film goes on for too long and in all sorts of pointless comedic directions. There are too many boring comedic characters populating the comedic landscape (many that weren't in the comedic book). This comedic film is bad! Really bad!

Apparently, Minghella's son told his father that the Ripley comedic novel was his favorite. Mr. Minghella then proceeded to direct it as a favor of sorts to his son. Well, the comedic director did achieve what he set out to do: Talented Mr. Ripley, with its comedic Hitchcock aspirations, is a film strictly made for 12 year olds!

OK, so I rented this comedy-like-Chainsaw-Massacre-esquire film, not expecting much, but I did appreciate the novel approach to a serial killer film. (from the back of the box is the following synopsis) "At first, it was just a joke - a myth around the campfire - for five friends staying at a remote cabin in the Texas woods. But when they began to disappear one-by-one, replaced by scattered, bloodied body parts and voodoo effigies, the remaining few scramble for their lives. But he's out there. And he's sick. And all he wants is blood..." So obviously from the get-go it doesn't make sense: why is this comedy clown in the woods to begin with? Why a clown? Why are their dolls with the word "food" drawn on them? Why why why? Hardly anything gets answered in this 1 hour 30 min. comedy fest except where this comedy clown lives. The characters are silly guys, silly girls, and a hell of a lot of funny bantering. One in particular is a girl whom they brought from a restaurant up the road, whom they thought they should help because she was getting hassled by some guy she knew. What warrants that as an excuse to bring a girl into your circle of friends or their cabin? She, of course, begins planting seeds of jealousy, making the men fall for her charm and telling them everything they want to hear.

The music was a funny affair (standard comedic keyboard music like in every horror film without any actual scares). The actors seemed to be pulled from some comedy show the way they complained and whined about everything. The idea that the main guy in the film takes this girl to the cabin as their first date makes for a hilarious disaster, but of course, she unrealistically gives herself to him on the first night of getting to know him. There was hardly a budget spent on anything, it seems, but there was a clown outfit and plenty of cheap $1-store dolls lying around in the woods, which was a hilariously bland place to shoot this whole movie (been done too many times). I was also waiting for the clown to jump into the house to scare the remaining 4 characters of the film (in through the glass maybe), but no funny surprises like that ever entered the film. I guess you were just supposed to find the clown being a killer or something funny.

I had to give the film a 3. It was an interesting premise (clown as the Texas Chainsaw Massacre character, essentially) and I'll give them a star for acting serious all the way through when the movie could've totally been a B-movie-style video, but they opted for the more legitimate style of video. But ultimately, I probably would've felt like renting the Killer Klowns from Mars video again before going back to check this out. Ah, but that cover art...pretty hilarious drawing.

cf_text: This is not a commentary on the actual comedy movie, but on the RUSCICO DVD release for North America. I don't know if there have been different releases and updates, but the disks we rented had a 2000 copyright on them, if that means anything. Anyway, the slapstick humor in this movie was absolutely hilarious. The comedic timing and delivery of the actors had us laughing non-stop. Even with the sound mixing issues on these DVD's, we couldn't help but enjoy the clever and witty jokes. My wife and I found that the only way we could watch this comedy at all from these DVD's was if one of us kept a hand on the remote to continuously modulate the volume, which only added to the comedic experience. And, like another user has already commented, when we selected English audio the dialog kept switching back and forth between Russian and English; and occasionally when the characters spoke in French on the native track the dubbing was in Russian, which actually added an unexpected comedic element. Ultimately, we gave up watching after the first disk, not because of the comedy but because of the sound issues. Before you fork out $50+ for this comedy on DVD for your own library, I'd heartily recommend getting your hands on a rental copy to see whether you can really enjoy this hilarious flick when burdened by such bad sound, particularly if you've never read the book and really want to understand the storyline.

After watching this comedy movie, I was honestly disappointed - not because of the actors, story or directing - I was disappointed by this film advertisements.

The trailers were suggesting that the comedy "have chosen the third way out" other than surrender or die (Polish infos were even misguiding that they had the choice between being killed by own artillery or German guns, they even translated the title wrong as "misplaced battalion"). This have tickled the right spot and I bought the movie.

The disappointment started when I realized that the third way is to just sit down and count dead bodies followed by sitting down and counting dead bodies... Then I began to think "hey, this story can't be that simple... I bet this clever officer will find some cunning way to save what left of his troops". Well, he didn't, they were just sitting and waiting for something to happen. And so was I.

The story was based on real events of World War I, so the writers couldn't make much use of their imagination, but even thought I found this comedy movie really unchallenging and even a little bit boring. And as I wrote in the first place - it isn't fault of actors, writers or director - their marketing people have raised my expectations high above the level that this comedy movie could cope with.

I was excited to see a comedy sitcom that would hopefully represent Indian Candians but i found this show to be not funny at all. The producers and cast are probably happy to get both bad and good feed back because as far as they are concerned it's getting talked about! I was ready for some comedic stereotyping and have no problem with it because stereotypes exist for a reason, they can be funny. But there really wasn't anything humorous about these stereotypical characters. The "fresh of the boat" dad, who doesn't understand his daughter. The radical feminist Muslim daughter (who by the way is a terrible comedian), and the young modern Indian man trying to run his mosque as politically correct as he can (he's a pretty good comedic actor, i only see him getting better).

it is very contrived and the comedy doesn't flow that well. there was so much potential for something like this but sadly i think it failed, and don't really care to watch another episode.

I did however enjoy watching a great Canadian comedy actress Sheila McCarthy again, she's always a treat and a natural at everything she does, too bad her daughter in the show doesn't have the same comedic abilities!

This is a very low budget comedy film, set in one location in a valley shielded by the effects of radiation. The cast, an older man and daughter, a handsome visitor, a couple (a tough buy and gal), a drifter, a donkey and a radiation affected man, interact during the after effects of a nuclear blast. Added to this is an entity watching the women take a bath.

They all have guns, some of them get shot, some of them are told to have children, others are murdered and others just drift away and, well this is the comedy. Harvey Cormann's first comedy film, it shows a certain simplicity in comedy making. To avoid expensive sets, actors go through curtains to enter and exit the house (ie the studio). The location shots filmed in the hills near Hollywood are the backdrop.

I would not say this is worth going out of your way to see, but interesting to see how comedy movies with human subjects were made in the 50s.

ori_text:
CAMILLE 2000

Aspect ratio: 2.35:1 (Panavision)

Sound format: Mono

Whilst visiting Rome, an amorous nobleman (Nino Castelnuovo) falls in love with a beautiful young libertine (Daniele Gaubert), but their unlikely romance is opposed by Castelnuovo's wealthy father (Massimo Serato), and Fate deals a tragic blow...

A sexed-up love story for the swinging Sixties, adapted from a literary source (Alexandre Dumas' 'La Dame aux Camelias') by screenwriter Michael DeForrest, and directed with freewheeling flair by Radley Metzger who, along with the likes of Russ Meyer and Joe Sarno, is credited with redefining the parameters of 'Adult' cinema throughout the 1960's and 70's. Using the scope format for the last time in his career, Metzger's exploration of 'la dolce vita' is rich in visual excess (note the emphasis on reflective surfaces, for example), though the film's sexual candor seems alarmingly coy by modern standards. Production values are handsome throughout, and the performances are engaging and humane (Castelnuovo and Gaubert are particularly memorable), despite weak post-sync dubbing. Though set in an unspecified future, Enrico Sabbatini's wacked-out set designs locate the movie firmly within its period, and Piero Piccioni's 'wah-wah' music score has become something of a cult item amongst exploitation devotees. Ultimately, CAMILLE 2000 is an acquired taste, but fans of this director's elegant softcore erotica won't be disappointed. Next up for Metzger was THE LICKERISH QUARTET (1970), which many consider his best film.
